Public API#

circle_bundles.api.build_bundle(data, cover, *, total_metric=None, cc='pca2', min_patch_size=10, weights=None, min_points_edge=5, ref_angle=0.0, delta_min_points=5, compute_witness=False, show=False, verbose=None)[source]#

Build a discrete circle bundle from data over a specified base-space cover.

This is the core end-to-end pipeline:

  1. ensure/build the cover (membership matrix U and partition of unity pou),

  2. compute local circle coordinates on each chart (local trivialization),

  3. estimate O(2) transition functions on overlaps,

  4. compute quality diagnostics, and

  5. compute characteristic class representatives (e.g. SW1/Euler-type data when available).

Parameters:

  • data (ndarray) – Data array of shape (n_samples, ambient_dim) representing points in the total space.

  • cover – Cover object over the base space. Must provide (after cover.build()): U (membership matrix), pou (partition of unity), and nerve accessors. If U/pou are missing, this function calls cover.build().

  • total_metric – Optional metric used by local trivialization routines (when they support it). If omitted, routines typically default to Euclidean behavior.

  • cc (object) – Local circle-coordinate method/config. Common choices include: - "pca2" for a fast PCA-based circle coordinate method, or - a Dreimac configuration object, or - a custom callable implementing your CC interface.

  • min_patch_size (int) – Minimum number of points required in a chart to attempt local trivialization. Charts with fewer points are treated as failures.

  • weights – Optional per-sample or per-overlap weights used in transition estimation (implementation-defined; pass only if you know the expected format).

  • min_points_edge (int) – Minimum number of overlap points required to fit a transition on an edge. Overlaps with fewer points are treated as errors.

  • ref_angle (float) – Reference angle (in radians) used to fix reflection conventions in O(2) fitting.

  • delta_min_points (int) – Minimum number of points used by certain consistency/quality checks on simplices.

  • compute_witness (bool) – If True, compute witness-based diagnostics (may be slower).

  • show (bool) – If True, display a summary visualization after construction.

  • verbose (bool | None) – If True, print status messages during construction. Defaults to show.

Returns:

A BundleResult packaging the cover, local trivialization, transitions, diagnostics, characteristic classes, and convenience methods.

Return type:

bundle

Raises:

ValueError: – If local trivialization fails on any chart or if required overlaps are missing.

class circle_bundles.api.BundleResult(cover, data, local_triv, cocycle, transitions, quality, classes, meta, total_metric=None, persistence=None, max_trivial=None, global_trivialization=None, bundle_map=None, _cache=<factory>)[source]#

Bases: object

Output of circle_bundles.bundle.build_bundle().

A BundleResult collects the user-facing artifacts of a discrete circle-bundle reconstruction:

  • a cover of the base space (charts, nerve, partition of unity),

  • a local trivialization (local circle coordinates on each chart),

  • an estimated O(2) cocycle (transition functions on overlaps),

  • quality diagnostics and characteristic class representatives,

  • plus cached convenience methods for downstream analysis and visualization.

Typical workflow#

Build a bundle:

>>> import circle_bundles as cb
>>> bundle = cb.build_bundle(data, cover, show=True)

Inspect already-computed outputs:

>>> bundle.classes
>>> bundle.quality

Compute and reuse cached downstream results:

>>> pers = bundle.get_persistence()
>>> mt = bundle.get_max_trivial_subcomplex()
>>> gt = bundle.get_global_trivialization()
>>> bm = bundle.get_bundle_map()
>>> pb = bundle.get_pullback_data()

Notes on caching#

Most user-facing computations are exposed as get_* methods which cache their result in bundle._cache. Passing recompute=True forces a fresh computation. Cached results may also be stored on a corresponding attribute (e.g. bundle.persistence) when the call uses default settings.

cover#

Cover object over the base space. Expected to provide: U (membership matrix), pou (partition of unity), landmark/base data (e.g. landmarks and base_points when applicable), and nerve accessors (nerve_edges(), nerve_triangles(), nerve_tetrahedra()).

Type:

Any

data#

Original data array of shape (n_samples, ambient_dim).

Type:

numpy.ndarray

local_triv#

Local trivialization result. Typically contains f (local angles per chart) and a valid mask over charts.

Type:

Any

cocycle#

Estimated cocycle / transition data. Typically provides Omega and (for oriented variants) theta.

Type:

Any

transitions#

Transition-fit report and per-overlap diagnostics (often includes per-edge RMS errors).

Type:

Any

quality#

Bundle quality diagnostics (consistency checks; optional witness errors when enabled).

Type:

Any

classes#

Characteristic class representatives (e.g. SW1 and Euler-type representatives when available).

Type:

Any

meta#

Lightweight provenance and default preferences used in construction.

Type:

circle_bundles.bundle.BundleMeta

compute_persistence(*, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, show=False)[source]#

Compute an edge-driven persistence-style filtration for class representatives.

This constructs a filtration of the nerve by assigning a scalar weight to each edge, then tracking when characteristic class representatives become coboundaries as edges are added in increasing-weight order.

Parameters:

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – Which built-in edge weight source to use when edge_weights is not provided. Common options are "rms" (transition RMS angle error) or "witness" (witness error), depending on what is available in this bundle. If omitted, defaults to bundle.meta["prefer_edge_weight"] (fallback: "rms").

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Explicit per-edge weights keyed by nerve edges (i, j). If provided, this overrides prefer_edge_weight.

  • show (bool) – If True, print a short summary of the resulting filtration / birth-death information.

Returns:

A persistence result object (implementation-defined) containing at least: - an ordered edge list / filtration - class-specific birth/death information used downstream.

Return type:

persistence

get_persistence(*, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, recompute=False, show=False)[source]#

Cached wrapper for compute_persistence().

Parameters:

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – See compute_persistence().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – See compute_persistence().

  • recompute (bool) – If True, ignore cached results and recompute.

  • show (bool) – If True, print a summary (passed through to compute_persistence()).

Returns:

The cached or newly computed persistence object.

Return type:

persistence

compute_max_trivial_subcomplex(*, persistence=None, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None)[source]#

Compute a maximal subcomplex on which selected class representatives become coboundaries.

Informally: this finds a large subcomplex (in the edge-driven filtration sense) where the obstruction information has “died,” so that trivializations / lifts can be constructed reliably on that subcomplex.

Parameters:

  • persistence – A persistence object as returned by get_persistence(). If omitted, it will be computed using prefer_edge_weight / edge_weights.

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – Used only when persistence is not provided. See get_persistence().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Used only when persistence is not provided. See get_persistence().

Returns:

A MaxTrivialSubcomplex containing kept/removed simplices and filtration index information.

Return type:

max_trivial

Raises:

ValueError: – If no such subcomplex is achieved (e.g. required codeath conditions never occur).

get_max_trivial_subcomplex(*, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, recompute=False)[source]#

Cached wrapper for compute_max_trivial_subcomplex().

Parameters:

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – See get_persistence().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – See get_persistence().

  • recompute (bool) – If True, ignore cached results and recompute.

Returns:

The cached or newly computed max-trivial subcomplex.

Return type:

max_trivial

compute_global_trivialization(*, method=None, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, orient=True, require_orientable=True)[source]#

Compute a global fiber coordinate on a max-trivial subcomplex.

This uses a subset of edges (typically from get_max_trivial_subcomplex()) and combines local trivializations into a single globally consistent fiber coordinate F.

Parameters:

  • method (str | None) – Global trivialization method identifier. If omitted, uses bundle.meta["trivialization_method"] (fallback: "singer").

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – Used to determine the max-trivial subcomplex when needed. See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Used to determine the max-trivial subcomplex when needed. See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • orient (bool) – If True, attempt to orient the cocycle on the chosen edge set and apply the induced gauge to local coordinates before trivializing.

  • require_orientable (bool) – If True and orient=True, raise an error when the cocycle cannot be oriented on the chosen edge set.

Returns:

A GlobalTrivializationResult containing a global coordinate array F and metadata.

Return type:

global_triv

Raises:

  • ValueError: – If orientation is required but not possible on the chosen edge set.

  • AttributeError: – If required cocycle fields (e.g. cocycle.theta) are missing.

get_global_trivialization(*, method=None, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, recompute=False, orient=True, require_orientable=True)[source]#

Cached wrapper for compute_global_trivialization().

Parameters:

  • method (str | None) – See compute_global_trivialization().

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • recompute (bool) – If True, ignore cached results and recompute.

  • orient (bool) – See compute_global_trivialization().

  • require_orientable (bool) – See compute_global_trivialization().

Returns:

The cached or newly computed global trivialization result.

Return type:

global_triv

get_frame_dataset(*, stage='post_projection', reducer=None, max_frames=None, rng_seed=None, edges=None, subcomplex='full', persistence=None, packing='coloring')[source]#

Build a frame dataset used by the bundle-map solver.

This is a lower-level helper primarily used to debug or experiment with the solver. Most users should call get_bundle_map() directly.

Parameters:

  • stage (str) – Which internal stage of the frame pipeline to return (implementation-defined).

  • reducer – Optional dimensionality reducer / frame selection configuration.

  • max_frames (int | None) – Optional cap on the number of frames generated.

  • rng_seed (int | None) – Random seed used when frame sampling is randomized.

  • edges (Iterable[Tuple[int, int]] | None) – Optional explicit edge list on which to build frames. If omitted, edges may be chosen based on subcomplex and persistence.

  • subcomplex (Literal['full', 'cocycle', 'max_trivial']) – Which edge set to use when edges is not provided: "full" uses all nerve edges; other modes use edges derived from persistence.

  • persistence – Persistence object required when subcomplex != "full".

  • packing (Literal['none', 'coloring', 'coloring2']) – Frame packing strategy (implementation-defined; affects which local frames are selected).

Returns:

A frame dataset object (implementation-defined) used as solver input.

Return type:

frames

get_bundle_map(*, edges=None, subcomplex='full', persistence=None, strict_semicircle=True, semicircle_tol=1e-08, reducer=None, packing='coloring', recompute=False, show_summary=False, compute_chart_disagreement=True)[source]#

Cached wrapper for compute_bundle_map().

Parameters:

  • edges (Iterable[Tuple[int, int]] | None) – Explicit edge set to use. If provided, subcomplex is ignored.

  • subcomplex (Literal['full', 'cocycle', 'max_trivial']) – If edges is not provided, choose edges from: "full" (all nerve edges), "cocycle", or "max_trivial" (derived from persistence).

  • persistence – Required when subcomplex != "full".

  • strict_semicircle (bool) – See compute_bundle_map().

  • semicircle_tol (float) – See compute_bundle_map().

  • reducer – See compute_bundle_map().

  • packing (Literal['none', 'coloring', 'coloring2']) – See compute_bundle_map().

  • compute_chart_disagreement (bool) – See compute_bundle_map().

  • recompute (bool) – If True, ignore cached results and recompute.

  • show_summary (bool) – If True, print a solver summary (passed through to compute_bundle_map()).

Returns:

The cached or newly computed BundleMapResult.

Return type:

bundle_map

bundle_app(*, get_dist_mat, initial_r=0.1, r_max=2.0, colors=None, densities=None, data_landmark_inds=None, landmarks=None, max_samples=10000, base_metric=None, rng=None)[source]#

Create a Dash application for interactive bundle exploration (does not run it).

This constructs and returns a Dash app object. To actually run the app, use show_bundle().

Parameters:

  • get_dist_mat – Callable used to compute pairwise distances among sampled points for interactive filtering. Signature is implementation-defined (typically get_dist_mat(X) -> (n,n)).

  • initial_r (float) – Initial distance threshold for the interactive neighborhood slider.

  • r_max (float) – Maximum value of the neighborhood slider.

  • colors – Optional per-sample colors (passed through to the viewer).

  • densities – Optional per-sample density visualizations or payloads (viewer-dependent).

  • data_landmark_inds – Optional indices mapping samples to landmarks (viewer-dependent).

  • landmarks – Optional base landmark coordinates. Defaults to cover.landmarks when available.

  • max_samples (int) – Maximum number of samples shown in the viewer (subsamples if needed).

  • base_metric – Optional base metric object used for landmark embedding / distances.

  • rng – Optional RNG used for subsampling.

Returns:

A Dash app instance.

Return type:

app

Raises:

ImportError: – If optional visualization dependencies (dash/plotly/scikit-learn) are not installed.

show_bundle(*, get_dist_mat=None, initial_r=0.1, r_max=2.0, colors=None, densities=None, data_landmark_inds=None, landmarks=None, max_samples=10000, base_metric=None, rng=None, debug=False, port=None)[source]#

Run the interactive Dash bundle viewer.

This is a convenience wrapper that constructs the app (see bundle_app()) and runs it in a local server.

Parameters:

  • get_dist_mat (Callable[[...], ndarray] | None) – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • initial_r (float) – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • r_max (float) – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • colors – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • densities – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • data_landmark_inds – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • landmarks – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • max_samples (int) – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • base_metric – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • rng – Passed through to bundle_app().

  • debug (bool) – If True, run the Dash server in debug mode.

  • port (int | None) – Optional port to bind the server to. If omitted, Dash chooses a default (or internal logic may pick a free port).

Returns:

The Dash app instance that was run.

Return type:

app

Raises:

ImportError: – If optional visualization dependencies (dash/plotly/scikit-learn) are not installed.

show_nerve(*, title=None, show_labels=True, show_axes=False, tri_opacity=0.25, tri_color='pink', cochains=None, edge_weight_source=None, edge_weights=None, edge_cutoff=None, highlight_edges=None, highlight_color='red')[source]#

Visualize the cover nerve (Plotly).

Parameters:

  • title (str | None) – Optional plot title.

  • show_labels (bool) – If True, display vertex labels.

  • show_axes (bool) – If True, show coordinate axes.

  • tri_opacity (float) – Appearance options for triangle faces (if present).

  • tri_color (str) – Appearance options for triangle faces (if present).

  • cochains (List[Dict[Tuple[int, ...], object]] | None) – Optional list of cochains to visualize (passed through to the cover nerve plotter).

  • edge_weight_source (str | None) – If edge_weights is not provided, choose a built-in source: "rms" (transition RMS error), "witness" (witness error), or "none". Defaults to bundle.meta["prefer_edge_weight"] when available.

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Explicit per-edge weights keyed by nerve edges (i, j).

  • edge_cutoff (float | None) – Optional cutoff threshold for displaying edges based on weight.

  • highlight_edges (Set[Tuple[int, int]] | None) – Optional set of edges to highlight.

  • highlight_color (str) – Color used for highlighted edges.

Returns:

A Plotly figure object (or whatever the cover’s show_nerve returns).

Return type:

fig

show_max_trivial(*, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights=None, recompute=False, title=None, show_labels=True, show_axes=False, tri_opacity=0.5, tri_color='pink', hide_removed_edges=True, highlight_removed=True, removed_color='red', highlight_kept=False, kept_color='green')[source]#

Visualize the max-trivial subcomplex (Plotly).

The max-trivial subcomplex is the largest subcomplex (in the edge-filtration sense) on which selected characteristic class representatives become coboundaries.

Parameters:

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – Used to compute the max-trivial subcomplex. See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • edge_weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Used to compute the max-trivial subcomplex. See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • recompute (bool) – Used to compute the max-trivial subcomplex. See get_max_trivial_subcomplex().

  • title (str | None) – Optional plot title.

  • show_labels (bool) – Display options for landmark labels / axes.

  • show_axes (bool) – Display options for landmark labels / axes.

  • tri_opacity (float) – Appearance options for triangle faces.

  • tri_color (str) – Appearance options for triangle faces.

  • hide_removed_edges (bool) – If True, draw only the kept edges (and triangles supported by kept edges).

  • highlight_removed (bool) – If True, highlight removed edges.

  • removed_color (str) – Color for removed edges when highlighted.

  • highlight_kept (bool) – If True, additionally highlight kept edges (thicker overlay).

  • kept_color (str) – Color for kept-edge highlighting overlay.

Returns:

A Plotly figure.

Return type:

fig

show_circle_nerve(*, use_max_trivial=True, prefer_edge_weight=None, edge_weights_for_max_trivial=None, recompute=False, omega=None, weights=None, phi=None, weights_source='rms', reorder_cycle=True, fail_if_not_cycle=True, auto_omega=True, compute_phi=True, phi_source='orient_if_possible', title=None, save_path=None, show=True, **kwargs)[source]#

Circle-layout nerve visualization for cycle graphs.

This helper is intended for covers whose nerve graph is a single cycle. It can display: - optional per-edge weights (e.g. RMS transition errors), - an O(1) cocycle omega when available, and - an optional vertex potential phi (orientation gauge) derived from orientability.

Parameters:

  • use_max_trivial (bool) – If True, compute and display the kept edge set from the max-trivial subcomplex.

  • prefer_edge_weight (str | None) – Options for computing the max-trivial subcomplex (used only when use_max_trivial=True).

  • edge_weights_for_max_trivial (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Options for computing the max-trivial subcomplex (used only when use_max_trivial=True).

  • recompute (bool) – Options for computing the max-trivial subcomplex (used only when use_max_trivial=True).

  • omega (Dict[Tuple[int, int], int] | None) – Optional O(1) data keyed by edges. If omitted and auto_omega=True, uses bundle.classes.omega_O1_used when available.

  • weights (Dict[Tuple[int, int], float] | None) – Optional per-edge weights. If omitted, weights_source chooses a built-in source.

  • phi (Dict[int, int] | None) – Optional vertex potential (e.g. ±1 per chart). If omitted and compute_phi=True, it will be computed from orientability logic (see phi_source).

  • weights_source (str) – Which built-in weight source to use when weights is omitted: "rms", "witness", or "none".

  • reorder_cycle (bool) – If True, reorder vertices along the cycle before plotting for a cleaner layout.

  • fail_if_not_cycle (bool) – If True, raise an error when the nerve is not a single cycle.

  • title (str | None) – Plot labeling/output options.

  • save_path (str | None) – Plot labeling/output options.

  • show (bool) – Plot labeling/output options.

  • kwargs – Passed through to the underlying circle-nerve visualizer.

  • auto_omega (bool)

  • compute_phi (bool)

  • phi_source (str)

Returns:

The underlying visualizer return value (often a Plotly/Matplotlib object depending on implementation).

Return type:

out

compare_trivs(*, ncols='auto', title_size=14, align=False, s=1.0, save_path=None, max_pairs=25, metric='mean', show=True, return_selected=False)[source]#

Compare local trivializations on overlaps (static diagnostic plot).

This renders a grid of overlap comparisons to help identify problematic chart pairs.

Parameters:

  • ncols (int | str) – Number of columns in the comparison grid (or "auto" to choose automatically).

  • title_size (int) – Font size for subplot titles.

  • align (bool) – If True, align trivializations before comparison (implementation-defined).

  • s (float) – Marker size scaling (visualization parameter).

  • save_path (str | None) – If provided, save the figure to this path.

  • max_pairs (int) – Maximum number of overlap pairs to display.

  • metric (str) – Scoring method used to rank/choose overlap pairs (implementation-defined; e.g. "mean").

  • show (bool) – If True, display the plot.

  • return_selected (bool) – If True, also return which overlap pairs were selected.

Returns:

Whatever the underlying compare_trivs returns (often a Matplotlib figure).

Return type:

fig_or_output

Parameters:

  • cover (Any)

  • data (ndarray)

  • local_triv (Any)

  • cocycle (Any)

  • transitions (Any)

  • quality (Any)

  • total_metric (Any)

class circle_bundles.api.BundleMapResult(F, pre_F, Omega_used, Phi_used, report, meta=<factory>)[source]#

Bases: object

Result of the bundle-map solver (global fiber coordinates from local trivializations).

The bundle-map solver takes: - cover data (membership matrix U and partition of unity pou), - local circle coordinates f on each chart, and - estimated transition functions Omega on overlaps,

and produces a globally consistent set of fiber coordinates (and supporting diagnostics).

Parameters:

  • F (ndarray)

  • pre_F (ndarray)

  • Omega_used (Dict[Tuple[int, int], ndarray])

  • Phi_used (ndarray)

  • report (Any)

  • meta (BundleMapMeta)

F#

Final global bundle coordinates of shape (n_samples, D_used) where D_used is the ambient frame dimension used by the solver at the moment it outputs coordinates (after optional packing / projection / reduction).

In the current implementation, F lives in the same ambient space as the projected frames used for gluing (i.e. columns correspond to the ambient coordinates of the Stiefel-projected frames).

Type:

numpy.ndarray

pre_F#

Per-chart (pre-gluing) coordinates of shape (n_charts, n_samples, D_used). For each chart j and sample s with U[j,s]=True, pre_F[j,s] stores the chartwise value F_j(s). Else it is zero.

This is the main object used to compute chart disagreement diagnostics.

Type:

numpy.ndarray

Omega_used#

The O(2)-valued cocycle actually used by the solver for diagnostics/gluing, stored as a dict (i,j) -> (n_samples,2,2) with canonical undirected edges. (This may differ from the raw simplicial cocycle on a restricted edge set, or after optional post-projection processing.)

Type:

Dict[Tuple[int, int], numpy.ndarray]

Phi_used#

The Stiefel-projected frames actually used for gluing, of shape (n_charts, n_samples, D_used, 2).

(Despite the name, this is not a ±1 orientation gauge vector; it is the frame field in the ambient space used by the solver.)

Type:

numpy.ndarray

report#

A solver report object (implementation-defined) with diagnostic statistics and warnings.

Type:

Any

meta#

Lightweight provenance (solver options such as semicircle constraints, packing mode, etc.).

Type:

circle_bundles.bundle.BundleMapMeta

class circle_bundles.api.PullbackTotalSpaceResult(total_data, metric, bundle_map, base_dim, fiber_dim, base_weight, fiber_weight, meta=<factory>)[source]#

Bases: object

Pullback total space data Z = (base | fiber) equipped with a product metric.

This object is returned by BundleResult.get_pullback_data(). It packages:

  • total_data: concatenation of base coordinates and computed fiber coordinates

  • metric: a product metric compatible with that concatenation

  • bundle_map: the underlying BundleMapResult used to build the fiber block

Parameters:

  • total_data (ndarray)

  • metric (Any)

  • bundle_map (BundleMapResult)

  • base_dim (int)

  • fiber_dim (int)

  • base_weight (float)

  • fiber_weight (float)

  • meta (PullbackMeta)

total_data#

Array of shape (n_samples, base_dim + fiber_dim) equal to np.concatenate([base, fiber], axis=1).

Type:

numpy.ndarray

metric#

Product metric on concatenated vectors. Typically an instance of ProductMetricConcat (or anything satisfying your Metric protocol).

Type:

Any

bundle_map#

The BundleMapResult used to obtain the fiber coordinates.

Type:

circle_bundles.bundle.BundleMapResult

base_dim#

Number of base columns in total_data.

Type:

int

fiber_dim#

Number of fiber columns in total_data.

Type:

int

base_weight, fiber_weight

Weights used by the product metric.

meta#

Provenance and options used to construct this pullback object.

Type:

circle_bundles.bundle.PullbackMeta

base_proj_map(X=None)[source]#

Project concatenated vectors onto their base block.

Parameters:

X (ndarray | None) – Optional array of concatenated vectors of shape (n, base_dim + fiber_dim). If omitted, projects self.total_data.

Returns:

The base block of shape (n, base_dim).

Return type:

base

to_text()[source]#

Return a short human-readable summary.

Returns:

A multi-line string describing array shapes and the metric name.
